title: 105_hr3497
content: The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" establishes individual investment accounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Individual Investment Account Act of 1998 allows individuals to deduct cash payments made to an individual investment account established for their benefit. An individual investment account is a trust created in the U.S. for the exclusive benefit of an individual, meeting specific requirements. An investment account is a trust in the U.S. for an individual's exclusive benefit, with specific requirements such as cash contributions and a trustee who meets certain criteria. An investment account in the U.S. requires a trustee who meets specific criteria, with no investment in collectibles and no commingling of assets. Contributions are deemed made on the last day of the tax year. "A taxpayer is deemed to have made a contribution on the last day of the taxable year if it is made on account of that year and before the deadline for filing the tax return. Distributions from an individual investment account are subject to specific tax treatment." The tax treatment of distributions from an individual investment account is generally included in gross income unless it qualifies as a first-time homebuyer distribution. Qualified 1st-time homebuyer distribution refers to a payment received by a first-time homebuyer from an individual investment account to be used for qualified acquisition costs within 120 days for a principal residence. Qualified 1st-time homebuyer distributions must be used within 120 days for qualified acquisition costs on a principal residence. The total amount for all taxable years cannot exceed $20,000, and the basis of the residence is reduced by the distribution amount. The basis of a principal residence is reduced by the amount of any qualified 1st-time homebuyer distribution, which must be used within 120 days for qualified acquisition costs. Transfer of an individual's interest in an investment account to a former spouse under a divorce decree is not considered a taxable transfer. Transfer of an individual's interest in an investment account to a former spouse under a divorce decree is not considered a taxable transfer. The interest at the time of the transfer is treated as an individual investment account of the spouse, exempt from taxation unless specified otherwise. For tax purposes, an individual investment account is exempt from taxation unless a prohibited transaction occurs, leading to loss of exemption. Individual investment accounts are tax-exempt unless a prohibited transaction occurs, resulting in loss of exemption under section 511. If a prohibited transaction occurs with an account under section 4975, it will lose its tax-exempt status as of the first day of the taxable year. The account will be treated as distributing all its assets on that day. On the first day of any taxable year, if an individual uses their investment account as security for a loan, that portion will be treated as distributed to them. If an individual uses their individual investment account as security for a loan, the portion used will be treated as distributed to them. Rollover contributions do not apply if the amount is paid into another individual investment account within 60 days. Individuals must maintain their account by transferring any distributed amount into another individual investment account within 60 days. The $20,000 limit in subsection (c)(2)(B) will be adjusted for inflation for taxable years after 1998. The dollar amount in subsection (c)(2)(B) will be increased by a cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year, rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. This adjustment applies to custodial accounts as well. The dollar amount in subsection (c)(2)(B) is increased by a cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year, rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. Custodial accounts are treated as trusts if held by a bank or another entity meeting specific criteria. The trustee of an individual investment account must provide reports to the Secretary and the account beneficiary. Custodial accounts are treated as trusts if held by a qualifying entity. The trustee of an individual investment account must provide reports to the Secretary and the account beneficiary regarding contributions, distributions, and other matters as required by regulations. These reports must be filed and furnished according to the regulations. Deductions are allowed in arriving at adjusted gross income. Individual investment accounts must provide reports to the Secretary and the account beneficiary as required by regulations. Deductions are allowed in arriving at adjusted gross income. Individual investment accounts are exempt from estate tax. "SEC. 2046. INDIVIDUAL INVESTMENT ACCOUNTS." Individual investment accounts, as defined in section 222(b), are excluded from the gross estate value and not subject to Section 1014. An exemption from the tax on prohibited transactions under Section 4975 is granted for transactions involving individual investment accounts. Individual investment accounts are exempt from the tax imposed by this section for transactions if the account ceases to be an individual investment account. Subsection (e)(1) is amended to include this exemption. The amendment includes adding an individual investment account as exempt from tax under section 222(d)(2)(A) and failure to provide reports on individual investment accounts under section 6693(a) of the Code is addressed. The amendment addresses failure to provide reports on individual investment accounts under section 6693(a) of the Code and adjusts the basis of residence acquired through the use of an account under section 1016. Clerical amendments are made to the table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendment adds new sections 2046 and 2047 regarding individual investment accounts and disclaimers. Effective date is for taxable years starting after December 31, 1997.
